etymologies: early 18th century: from Latin sessilis, from sess- ‘seated’, from the verb sedere

definitions: (of an organism, e.g. a barnacle) fixed in one place; immobile

examples.text: parrotfish inadvertently graze upon sessile invertebrates when cropping algae
overall body shape is consistent with a sessile habit

shortDefinitions: of organism fixed in one place

definitions: (of a plant or animal structure) attached directly by its base without a stalk or peduncle

examples.text: sporangia may be stalked or sessile

shortDefinitions: (of plant or animal structure) attached directly by its base without stalk or peduncle
